chargeHist.descr: Take and Drive Vehicle w/o Consent

result.execSummary:
The defendant Cory M Kreklow was found guilty of the following charge(s) in this case.

  • Take and Drive Vehicle w/o Consent, a class H felony, Wisconsin Statutes 943.23(2).

Notice to employers: It may be a violation of state law to discriminate against a job applicant because of an arrest or conviction record. Generally speaking, an employer may refuse to hire an applicant on the basis of a conviction only if the circumstances of the conviction substantially relate to the particular job. For more information, see Wisconsin Statute 111.335 and the Department of Workforce Development's publication, Arrest and Conviction Records under the Law.

supervisions.notes:
The Court sentences Mr. Kreklow to  3 years, with an Initial Term of Confinement in Prison of 18 months and the maximum time to serve on Extended Supervision of 18 months. 

The Court STAYS this Sentence and places Mr. Kreklow on Probation for two years, with conditions (which will become conditions of Extended Supervision if Probation is revoked, with the exception of the jail term)

miscConds.notes:
--the restitution amount that Mr. Kreklow is to pay to the victims [James Kreklow and Vickie Kreklow] is $3750 ($250 for the insurance deductible and $3,500 for increased insurance premiums).  The Court will allow Mr. Kreklow to pay this restitution directly to his parents, using a money order or cashiers check; the $100 weekly payments are to commence next week.  The payments are to be monitored by the Agent.   

--Mr. Kreklow is to pay restitution to his ability

Per Standing Order Defendant to pay 10% restitution surcharge

The Court orders that at the end of Mr. Kreklow's conditional jail time, any unpaid restitution amount will be converted to a civil judgment in favor of the victims.

--to pay costs and fees

Per Standing Order Defendant to pay $10 drug diversion surcharge
--Mr. Kreklow is to attempt to maintain full time employment and/or education programming or a combination of these
--no use of illegal drugs or alcohol

--Mr. Kreklow is to obey the law

--to continue with any medical treatment including mental health treatment recommended

The Court does not order Mr. Kreklow to comply with DNA sample provision, because it is known that Mr. Kreklow has already provided a DNA sample in previous felony conviction cases.

Arresting Agency: JCSD

If probation, parole or extended supervision is revoked or discharged with outstanding financial obligations, a civil judgment shall be entered against the defendant and in favor of the victim(s) and government entities for the balance due.

records.addlTxt: Huber Law/Work Release Notification

Reserve Judge Davis presiding for Branch IV: 
[MK] case called at 11:24am. 
Defendant Cory M Kreklow in court with Attorney Sylvie H Dahnert.  ADA Brookellen Teuber appears for the State of Wisconsin.
Maximum penalties recited; Constitutional rights reviewed; plea of " Guilty " entered; factual basis stipulated; victim rights compliance verified; the Court accepts plea, finds Defendant guilty, and orders Judgment of Conviction entered.
During the Sentencing portion of the hearing, a statement is given by victim James Kreklow and Vickie Kreklow. 

The Court sentences Mr. Kreklow to  3 years, with an Initial Term of Confinement in Prison of 18 months and the maximum time to serve on Extended Supervision of 18 months. 
The Court finds that Mr. Kreklow is eligible for the Challenge Incarceration Program "Boot Camp" and for the Substance Abuse Program.
The Court gives  91 days credit for time already served.

The Court STAYS this Sentence and places Mr. Kreklow on Probation for two years, with conditions (which will become conditions of Extended Supervision if Probation is revoked, with the exception of the jail term):  
---to serve 9 months in Jefferson County Jail, with work release privileges; to commence on May 1, 2016 at 6:00pm; the work release is conditioned upon Mr. Kreklow making restitution payments of $100 per week, payable the first Monday after the first full week he is incarcerated.  If Mr. Kreklow does not make restitution and his work-release privileges are revoked because of this, Mr. Kreklow is to have his work-release privileges reinstated if he catches up in restitution payments  
--the restitution amount that Mr. Kreklow is to pay to the victims [James Kreklow and Vickie Kreklow] is $3750 ($250 for the insurance deductible and $3,500 for increased insurance premiums).  The Court will allow Mr. Kreklow to pay this restitution directly to his parents, using a money order or cashiers check; the $100 weekly payments are to commence next week.  The payments are to be monitored by the Agent.   
--Mr. Kreklow is to pay restitution to his ability
--Mr. Kreklow is to obey the law
--Mr. Kreklow is to attempt to maintain full time employment and/or education programming or a combination of these
--to continue with any medical treatment including mental health treatment recommended
--no use of illegal drugs or alcohol
--to pay costs and fees

The Court orders that at the end of Mr. Kreklow's conditional jail time, any unpaid restitution amount will be converted to a civil judgment in favor of the victims.  
The Court does not order Mr. Kreklow to comply with DNA sample provision, because it is known that Mr. Kreklow has already provided a DNA sample in previous felony conviction cases.
Felony firearm, body armor and voting prohibition warnings given. 
recess 12:05pm.  
The Court gives the non-citizen related deportion warnings to Mr. Kreklow.
recess 12:06pm.
